headline: Kalua Pig in a Slow Cooker
description: This kalua pork recipe seasons a pork butt roast which simmers in the slow cooker for fall-apart tender pork without digging a hole in your backyard!

video.description: See how to make amazing Hawaiian-style pork.
video.name: Kalua Pig in a Slow Cooker

name: Kalua Pig in a Slow Cooker

recipeInstructions.text: Pierce pork all over with a carving fork; rub in salt then liquid smoke. Transfer pork into a slow cooker.
Cover, and cook on Low for 16 to 20 hours, turning once during cooking time.
Remove pork from slow cooker; shred with two forks, adding drippings as needed to moisten.

review.reviewBody: The best way to cook this roast. I use pork loin w/rib meat that is good too.
Make sure you remove the skin if there is any on it. It doesn't need to be cooked for 16-20 hrs. 8-10 hours on low works fine. Also it doesn't need any broth/water added.

Loved this! Made it for Christmas/football gathering and it was a hit. Served with small rolls and sides of sweet pickles and banana peppers, and a macaroni salad. Used an 8lb bone in pork shoulder and Morton’s coarse sea salt and liquid smoke. Before returning shredded pork to juices, strained juices into a fat separator. That helped cut down on the grease. Will definitely make again!!!

Amazing!! I added 1/4 cup of chicken broth at the beginning, out of concern for it burning. Turned out amazing!! Since, I begin with the fat down, and don’t add anything else. It takes me back to the day I first hit Hawaii and was starving, waiting for our rental car, and my sweetheart of a girlfriend walked down the street for food and brought back this same amazing Kalua pork. Taste takes me back to that time every time. Bittersweet. Amazing recipe, and SO EASY! Thank you for sharing.
Where's the cabbage?
Slow cooked for 16 hours. Melted like butter and tastes great. Could not find any Hawaiian sea salt but used regular sea salt.
It is delicious. I have made it many times. Last time I was out of liquid smoke. Replaced it with smoked paprika and it was just as good.

It was close to Hawaiian pork we would get in Maui! Very delicious. I used Kiwei smoked salt, so I cut down on the smoke. Way way down, to just a few drops. Even with a non smoked salt, I think a tablespoon of liquid smoke would be overpowering Other than that, the only other issue is with all slow cooked food vs. smoked food, it tastes similar, but the texture is different (more mushy with crockpots) I would definitely do again, so easy and tasty

This is wonderful! I have made it several times, using hickory liquid smoke, and this last time with applewood liquid smoke-both work great (I usually end up using a couple TBS to cover the roast thoroughly), as does using kosher salt (I never have Hawaiian salt available) If you put it in a big bowl in the fridge overnight, most fat congeal on the top for easy removal. This is great plain, or you can add BBQ sauce or salsas and make sandwiches, tacos, burritos- whatever you are in the mood for! My family loves it! One tip, my big oval Crockpot has 3 settings: Hi, Lo and Warm. I start this for an hour or two on Lo, then switch to Warm for the last 16 hours or so, as the 2 higher temps are too much for the long, slow cook time. Delicious!

I've been making this for years and it is always a big hit! I usually add just a little extra liquid smoke at the end if it needs it. Gotta taste it! Cole slaw with some pineapple in it on top of a little sammie, delish!
Love, love, love this!!! I have made this sooo many times. My friend from Hawaii said it's better than hers! I didn't change anything.
Came out dry, and the bottom burned,. Flavor remains good. will add a bit a liquid. next time.

I’ve been making Kalua Pig in my slow cooker for several years, compliments of my daughter, and it never fails. But… to make it taste like the authentic stuff you need to use Mesquite liquid smoke. Kiawe wood (a sweeter type of Mesquite) is used in Hawaii. It gives the meat that special flavor. You can find it next to the hickory stuff in the grocery store.
Loved it!
Been making this for years and it always gets rave reviews! The hardest part is leaving the lid on the cooker until it's done!

So easy. So Good. Huge hit. I looked at over 30 recipes to "get" this right. There was no mention of the huge fat flap to keep or remove. I keep it when I cook in the oven for Puerto Rican Pernil. But chose to remove it for a slow cooker. Good choice. I had no Hawaiian salt, I used Kosher Coarse Salt. I cooked as is but adjusted the salt/smoke to the meat weight. It's all a matter of preference. 3/4 way thru I added more smoke. The huge part of this is after the meat is shredded and defatted, to put it back in with the juices and cook another hour or so. The flavor is in the juice! If you miss this step, you miss all the yummy flavor. I added a touch more smoke again for my taste. Perfect. I fretted over the missing details. Hope this helps.
Fantastic recipe, used Kiawe liquid smoke which you can find on Amazon, as well as Alaea Hawaiian sea salt . Tastes as good as what they serve in Hawaii.

Very good. I only had table salt and can now say that a tablespoon of regular salt is a little too much. I also think there must be a difference in brands of liquid smoke as I found one tablespoon to not be enough. Finally, my slow cooker has a low setting that is much hotter than other slow cookers. My pork was completely tender in eight hours, so knowing your crockpot is important. Very delicious. I might make it for Christmas!

I followed the recipe....after shredding meat, I did not want to add the drippings/juices from the crock pot as it is all grease. Instead, I added beef broth for enhancing the flavor. I have family members who like barbecue sauce and others plain. I will definitely make again!

I have made this multiple times, using smoked salt that I bring beck from Kauai. I cut back on the amount of salt or it is too salty - same with the Liquid Smoke. Remove some of the liquid as it accumulates and refrigerate to separate the fat - and there is a lot!

Wow.. this is crazy good and so so simple. I have done pulled pork shoulder many different ways some involved complex marinating and cooking techniques.. but this beats them all hands down and with only three ingredients. I did follow a suggestion in the comments and I put a banana in the slow cooker with the meat.. so maybe 4 ingreedients. EXCELENT and EASY
DELICIOUS!!! Used a boneless pork shoulder roast, and kosher salt. It was done cooking in 9 or 10 hours.

I've made this recipe hundreds of times. I use it for shredded bar-b-q pork, shredded pork in a burrito, shredded pork in my chili. Whatever you want to add this to, it will be delicious. I highly recommend it and it's super easy.
Easy and delicious!

I’ve made this recipe for years now and it is always a crowd pleaser. My slow cooker doesn’t require 16-20 hours, but suggest flipping the pork around 4 hours. I shred the meat as well to absorb some of the juice. Love it.

this is the best! I made my 2lbs pork roast the exact way its instructed on the recipe except I couldnt find hawiian salt at my store so I used pink Himalayan salt and then added a little bit of water to the crock pot so my meat wouldnt dry out. after about 16-17 hours of cooking it came out perfect. I served it with white rice, seaweed, homemade macaroni salad, and yeast rolls and my family loved it.
Very simple and taste great. The only changes I made were to butterfly the pork to increase the salt/smoke penetration, and serving the meat in slices, ala roast.
Perfect & simple. Cooked 3lbs, added shredded cabbage and pineapple after 10hrs & shredding. Cooked another hour on low. Definitely will be my go-to recipe.
Loved it! It’s my favourite meal when we visit Hawaii! I just made an account to give 5 stars!

I know it's not traditional, but I add an onion and a few cloves of garlic. I also add a green banana (peel and all) to mimic the banana leaves it would be wrapped in for a pit. When it's done cooking, I remove the peel and shred everything else together. Delicious!
So good and so easy! We use the black Hawaii salt
I used the correct salt and it was still too salty. But it was delicious. Served it with white rice and macaroni salad. A perfect Hawaiian meal!
Amazing!

Very good. I used a piece just over 6 lbs. I am a "salt-a-holic" and still would suggest to use a little under the 1 1/2 TBS. I was perfectly salted for me but if I was serving it to company, I would be afraid that it would be too salty for them. I would actually increase the liquid smoke next time to 1 1/2 TBS to see how that would taste.
So good and so easy.

So simple and amazing. Great flavor, no need to ruin it with typical mainland sauces. Plated it with Hawaiian Potato Mac salad recipe from Polynesian Cultural Center and Kings sweet bread for personal Luau.

I use pork shoulder. I Pierce the raw shoulder, all over, rub with coarse sea salt, put it in the Crock-Pot skin/fat side up, with 2 whole bottles of liquid smoke, and cook it on low for 10 hours. Perfect and juicy every time. When it's done, I take it out, remove the big chunks of fat, and the shoulder blade, shred it the meat, then put all the meat back in the Crock-Pot with all the juice/liquid smoke. Then serve. We like to eat it on rolls, or just by itself. I'm not sure how you can get much flavor with just 2 tablespoons of the liquid smoke. That sounds kind bland and dry.
Great recipe. One of our regulars!

I've done half the recipe size and cut the time in half and do at high. I don't have the called for salt and use pink Himalaya salt instead. It doesn't always come out salty or juicy enough so I add salt to my own portion. Nothing compares to the pork we had in Maui though

Couldn't have been easier to make. Just followed the simple instructions, using black Hawaiian salt, and served on home made pretzel rolls. There are a LOT of recipes for pulled pork, so this has to deal with that competition, but we found it a good change.

This is delicious and I will make it again, but doesn’t taste like traditional Kalua pork, though... I’m sure that traditional Polynesians didn’t use crock pots to cook their pork thus the difference in texture and flavor. Traditional underground imu is used to make Kalua pork. Wrapped in Multiple types of leaves from the islands that give it a unique and delicious flavor. Any time I travel to the islands, I make sure to get the real stuff... it’s not replicable in the kitchen. This receptor is delicious thousand.

I made this as per recipe except for draining the liquid, cooling it, skimming the congealed fat (about 80%), and returning. Also added shredded cabbage as per ES. Nobody disliked it but nobody loved it either. I think the cabbage helps though I found it dry and rather without flavor, except salt. The wife ate it on Hawaiian sweet roll buns and liked that better. On the plus side it makes a lot from a very inexpensive cut of meat.
I added 2 green bananas (For background bitterness) and a bottle of soy sauce (less salt). Excellent!
Serve with fresh pineapple salsa
This was my first attempt at pulled pork and WOW was it easy and tasty.
Tasty and simple. Not quite out-of-the-pit flavor, but close enough for how little effort this recipe requires.
The most flavorful pork ever, So easy to make, Works with bone in pork butt too! Wonderful!!!!!

This is my go to potluck dish for any season. It is so simple and so delicious!!!!! I have made this over 8x and every time it's a hit. You can't go wrong. I serve with Hawaiian rolls and slaw on the side, plus bbq for those that want it but it really does not need it. Enjoy!
This is a very simple and easy recipe. After 20 hours in the slow cooker, the meat practically shredded itself. I thought it was good, but my kids raved about it.
Awesomw. Even approved by a Mainland Hawaiian. :)

This was amazing! I found the specified salt and made exactly as directed. I was a bit nervous leaving it to simmer unattended all day, but it was so tender when done. I started it at 2am and we ate around 6pm - it was 7-8lbs. I enjoyed sandwiches for weeks with the leftovers! We will be having this for Christmas!
In just curious what flavor of smoke flavor because there are a few to chose from. Apple, mesquite, hickory.

This was delicious!!!! I made an 8.5 lb pork roast in my slow cooker last week and it was brought to feed us fam of 4 twice plus have enough for two meals in the freezer. I was afraid that this would be too salty and smoky since every time I’ve eaten kalua pork at a restaurant that’s been the case but my hubby loves restaurant kalua pork so I gave it a shot with this recipe and I could not be more pleased with the results. I had to increase the portion amount for my larger cut of meat using the all recipes calculator and it work perfectly. The salt level and the smoke level were absolutely perfect. My final concern was that 20 hours would be too long and the meat might begin to deteriorate or dry out and be flavorless... it was PERFECT. Totally worth the wait and I will do this easy recipe over again regularly.
Cooking time was spot on, just thought it came out bland ifor my taste.

This is sooooo good. I have made it many times but have never gotten around to leaving a review. 

I know the time seems long but do NOT change it. Also, I used the real Hawaiian salt. I did have to hunt it down but it is really worth it. I followed this recipe exactly. Thanks for such a delicious recipe.

I would make this again. I made it for a group of a little more than 20 people so I used about 8-9 lbs of pork. Couldn’t find Hawaiian sea salt so I settled for Trader Joe’s sea salt. Used Stubbs liquid smoke. I let the slow cooker heat up for about 20 mins and cut the pork into chunks to help with thorough cooking and rubbed down the meat with the sea salt. Left on low for about 22 hours. My sister made a great coleslaw to top it and guests could chose their bbq sauce if they wanted some. I even had someone who cooks slow cooked pork from the south come back for seconds. This is a BIG crowd pleaser!

I was given this recipe from a family at church who are from Hawaii, so it's the real deal! So easy. There's nothing more to do than poke, salt, and rub! When adding the liquid smoke, either use a brush to apply or wear gloves to rub it on to save yourself from stained stinky hands! I don't measure the Hawaiian salt nor the liquid smoke, just generously apply both after poking lots of holes. I use a large carving-type fork that has long substantial tines so it goes deeply into the meat (all around) with minimal effort. After pulling the meat apart I add enough of the cooking liquid to moisten it, and then use the rest to make sticky rice in my rice cooker. So if it calls for 1 cup of water I use approx. 1/4 c. pig juice and 3/4 c. water, depending on how salty the juice is. It makes great rice! You couldn't make an easier or tastier piece of meat. Also, I like to get 2-3 smaller boneless pork roasts (I have a large slow cooker so several 2-3 lb roasts fit) instead of one large roast. 
 I have tried it both ways and prefer the tenderness and quicker cooking time using multiple smaller roasts. You won't be disappointed with this easy and delicious recipe. I make so much for just one person because it freezes very well. After pulling the pork and making the flavored sticky rice, I just portion both together into a meal size container and pop into the freezer! I usually end up with enough to eat for 3 dinners when freshly made, give 2 portions to a friend, and have
Absolutely delicious. Taste just like the Kailua Pig in Hawaii.

Given I grew up with authentic Kalua pig, I suggest adding 1 more tablespoon of liquid smoke.

I slowed cook in crock-pot for ~ 15 hours
I ordered Hawaiian Pa'Akai Alaea Sea Salt for this. This dish was amazing! I will make it often!
this was soooooo easy and tasty!

I lived Maui for 2 years .. so we crave this and not much Hawaiian food in Texas . I made this it was amazing ! And we had so much leftover it lasted the whole week. Ordered the red salt on amazon from Molokai. The only thing I did different was add a bunch of garlic cloves inserted all over the pork . Add cabbage in the last hour . I like with Mac with macaroni salad .. and Hawaiian rolls . Ono

Super tender, husband just loved it. The thing he didn’t love was the smell because there wasn’t one. He was expected an aroma wafting thru the house when we walked in the door (like other crockpot meals) but nothing. Nonetheless, it was amazing...in a sandwich, combined with rice, eaten alone. Thumbs up!
Love it. My Hawaiian friend makes it the same way.

I used a 9lb roast so increased the liquid smoke to 1 1/2 Tablespoons and 2 Tablespoons of ground pink sea salt. Cooked on low for 10 hours, then removed fat cap, flipped roast and cooked the final 10 hours. FANTASTIC!
Always delicious

I make this all the time!! (Although, I add other seasonings to the rub as well, just for more flavor.)
It's just so versatile! 
Sauce it or not. Use in sandwhiches, tacos, on salads, as a main entree..... I can find 1000 uses for it. 
I make a big batch on a Sunday and I use it for the rest of the week!

The roast I picked up was to large for one slow cooker so I had to cut it in half and use two slow cookers. I did not think to cut the ingredients in half as well so too salty without BBQ sauce. Otherwise, fantastic. Will make again, correctly, soon.

I make this recipe every 3-4 weeks. I eat it plain or with cabbage cooked in the juice first night and then use it in nachos/ tacos, omelets and soups. It freezes great!I I still can't believe how easy and delicious this is.

Simple and delicious. But you have to make cabbage & white rice with it!
To make the cabbage, shred it about an hour before dinner. Put it in it's own pot and add a cup or cup & a half of the juices out of the pork. Add a little black pepper & simmer for the better part of an hour. Serve the cabbage over some rice along with the shredded pork and some Sri Racha pepper sauce.

This is absolutely amazing! The 2nd time I made this, I increased to 9 pounds to have lots of leftovers. We serve this over rice. Super quick prep (most intensive part is taking all the fat off before serving, but well worth it!). LOVE THIS!
A family favorite. Great for weeknight meals and reminds us of the real thing we had in Hawaii!
we loved it. I did marinate for a few hours to soak up the salt. it's going to be a new family favorite.

Made it last night, it turn out great. I added a little Chinese five spices, and wrap it in banana leaves. Set it in slow cooker at high for 4 hours and keep warm for the next 4 hours. I also wrap the cooker cover with plastic food wrap to keep the moisture in pot.

As i do on a regular basis. I make the recipe as written first time around then add or delete from there the next time i make it.
This one is perfect just the way it is. 

The family loves it! I start the roast (never smaller than 3 lbs or i dont get any) the night before on low, by the next morning it is fall apart tender. 
Shred what needs it put it back in the crock add the cabbage and let it cook for another half to one hr on low so it can soak up all the.delicious juices. 
Perfect every time.
Just like living on the island ,take your time.No rush.all good things come to those that wait.

I made this in my Instant Pot. I used olive oil and browned the pork on sauté on all sides (about a minute or so a side). I removed the pork and set it aside, then added the water and liquid smoke to the pot and put the pork back in. I used Himalayan salt, grinding it over the top of the pork (I used less than half what the recipe called for). Set the timer for 90 minutes, followed by a 20 minute natural release and done. It was the best Kulua pork I’ve ever had, not fatty or greasy. My family loved it.
leftovers become pulled pork sandwhiches

This was the best roast I’ve ever made! I used black lava salt as others suggested and agree with them on the added flavor dimension. Also, just so happens I was finishing up a bag of smoked almonds. I scooped up about a tablespoon of the seasoning from the bottom of the bag and rubbed it all over the roast along with the salt. It was large - over 9 lbs - and had been neatly tied up by the butcher. There was a good covering of fat on one side. I made slices along that side and poured just one teaspoon mesquite liquid smoke over it. Still can’t believe how delicious this recipe turned out yet was so simple.
Outstanding dish! Easy to make and tender as heck and very flavorful. I love it!

Take the meat out and shred it ~1 hour before it’s “done” and mix in some shredded cabbage ~30 minutes early. Cook the cabbage just enough to soften it, but still leave in a bit of crunch. Serve with rice for a great Hawaiian lunch plate!
I've made this at least a dozen times over the years just as written and it's a favorite every single time!
Made it for a work pot luck and it was delicious...everyone enjoyed it! I added the banana split open on the top, not sure if it really changed the flavor...but definitely worth the try.

This is one of my family's all time favorites. I throw in a handful of garlic cloves and shortened the cook time to about 16 hrs. I usually sauté some mushrooms in a brown gravy mix and add those in after I shred the pork. It adds a little more sauce, just in case.

I love Boston Butt roasts because they're so tender and flavorful and they taste great when cooked in a slow cooker all day. This recipe is very similar to how I make pork for pulled pork sandwiches. 

It came out great! I couldn't find Hawaiian salt in time, so I substituted pink Himalayan salt. It was still delicious but I definitely want to try it with the Hawaiian salt.

I served it with an Asian inspired coleslaw (shredded cabbage, carrots, green onions, and cilantro with a store bought ginger dressing) and macaroni and cheese. I looked up traditional Hawaiian sides and didn't have access to some ingredients. I found out macaroni salad is a traditional side dish, but my kids hate mayonnaise. Someone else suggested that macaroni and cheese is also traditional, so I made that because the kids love it. We also served it with yeast rolls because none of us care for the sweet Hawaiian rolls. All the components of the meal complimented each other really well.

I will definitely be making this again!
Awesome. Everyone loved it and asked for the recipe.
This was fantastic!! I never cooked anything for this long of a time in a slow cooker so I was hesitant and skeptical but it turned out beautifully.

Comes out perfect every time! I’ve cooked it for 12-20 hours, depending on how early I remember to start it :) I used red Hawaiian salt and black Hawaiian salt and an extra TBS of liquid smoke cause I love that stuff. Don’t know if it made a difference but I also sliced a banana in half and placed it on top of the roast. Discard it when it’s all done. I pull the roast out before serving, to let it cool a little so I can shred it... while it’s cooling I use a gravy separator with the juices (usually just adding ice to it so the fat floats to the top) and pour back in most of the juices sans the fat. Add back in the now shredded pork, let it warm back up a bit and dinner is done :) served with rice of course.Never been to Hawaii but it tastes just like the one I had served at a Hawaiian restaurant and my hubby says it’s on par with the real thing in Hawaii. So thank you! :)
Made it for the time— it turned out amazing. I never thought with just “3” ingredients I could make this awesome dish. Tastes the BEST!!!
My family loves this!!!!!
Made it according to the recipe several times and was always wonderful. Going to make it again and this time try a half and half mixture of bot the red and black sea salt.

I've made this many times and have never cooked it that long. My 6 quart slow cookers fits two of the "tri tip pork roasts" (sold in pkg of 3 at Costco). Its well trimmed pork butt I believe and is nice and lean. I never flip it and just add a bit of water or broth and cook on high for a couple hours and then on low for 6-7 hours. A forgiving recipe, that is great with rice, or as a base for tacos or burritos. Easy and very lean.

This is an acceptable recipe. However, it is missing half of its flavor. When I had to transfer from Hawaii to NY then OH and VA I would order from my local florist two banana leaves and one bunch of ti leaves. Wash them thoroughly and then trim the green leaf off of the spine of the banana (one leaf equals two long green strips. discard the spine). On the back of each ti leaf, gently press a knife blade across the spine to break it. Fold the leaf and peel the bottom half off the spine of the leaf. Next, depending upon the size of your meat, lay out a big square of foil. Then make a flower in the center of it with all your ti leaves (tips together in the center. Then lay your four larger banana leave on top in a crisscross or basket weave pattern. Take your meat and rub it generously with sea salt. Center it on the leaves. sprinkle well with Keawe/Mesquite liquid smoke. Fold the banana leaf up flat over the meat. Then, repeat by bringing each petal of the ti leaves up and over. Finally, bring the foil up and over and tightly wrap so that all the leaves are completely covered/secured. I put a small wire rack in the bottom of my slow cooker and fill with water to the bottom of the wire. Then I sit the foil package on it and put it on low for about 16-20 hours. The leaves are a very traditional way of cooking the meat in the imu and they impart a flavor that is subtle and so 'ono (delicious) also, they help absorb fat. When the dish is done, take the lid off and peel the foil
Easy and so delicious!
I didn't make any changes and it came out delicious! Very simple, straightforward recipe. Love it!!

The pictures with this recipe does not do it justice. My family spends a great deal of time in Maui. We love authentic Kalua pork with Ti Leaves but you can't really get those on the mainland. I'm sooooooooo tired of bbq pulled pork. I like the smoky-saltiness of kalua style. This recipe is not only extremely easy, it's the closest I get to the real thing. It's our go-to meat for crowds or multiple meals. You can eat it alone, on a hawaiian bun/rolls, as lettuce wraps, stuffed potato skins, salads you name it. Love this recipe.

Wife and I just made this last night in our slow cooker. We bought a 6lb pork shoulder for this. Don't have Hawaiian sea salt in our local stores (looked in asian and non-asian). We substituted Himalayan Pink salt instead. Had a hard time finding liquid smoke as well, Googled a substitute and found some smoked paprika. Cooked in slow cooker for 9 hours and we wrapped our in banana leaf. Didn't turn the roast over due to the banana leaf would have torn. We did add about 3-4 ounces of water..since we were uncertain if the banana leaf would burn in the slow cooker.

We found it okay..not super special or outstanding. We have not tried traditional kalua pork, so we don't have a means of comparison or reference.

The side of the meat that was in contact with the liquid was easier to shred than the side that wasn't (of course). The smoked paprika flavor did come through as did the infused flavor of the banana leaf. After shredding with 2 forks, i put all back in the slow cooker with the juices (removed the banana leaf). The shredded pork did gain the flavoring from the juices.

However, found this difficult to eat with rice, not saucy enough for our palate. I did use some in a wrap with some hickory smoked bbq sauce and it was fine. If you prefer pulled pork this is 1 way to go if you intend to use your favorite sauce and some veggies with it in a sandwich/wrap.

However, we prefer this one for making a pulled pork style dish : https://www.allrecipes.com/recipe/141678/
so easy , so good, very tasty !!!
PERFECT RECIPE. WE USE IT FOR SLIDERS, TACOS AND OTHER QUICK MEALS.
Didn’t believe it would be as good as it was with so few ingredients.... Amazing...I’d definitely make this again and again!!!
